column2: In what way?
column3: In what way?

column2: Why, the fair is on at Beaucaire, there are always jewellers from Paris there, and I will show it to them.	Why, the fair is on at Beaucaire, there are always jewellers from Paris there, and I will show it to them.

column2: Look after the house, wife, and I shall be back in two hours," and Caderousse left the house in haste, and ran rapidly in the direction opposite to that which the priest had taken.
column3: Look after the house, wife, and I shall be back in two hours," and Caderousse left the house in haste, and ran rapidly in the direction opposite to that which the priest had taken.

column2: Fifty thousand francs! muttered La Carconte when left alone; "it is a large sum of money, but it is not a fortune."
column3: Fifty thousand francs! muttered La Carconte when left alone; "it is a large sum of money, but it is not a fortune."

column2: Chapter 28.
column3: Chapter twenty eight.

column2: The Prison Register.
column3: The Prison Register.

column2: The day after that in which the scene we have just described had taken place on the road between Bellegarde and Beaucaire, a man of about thirty or two and thirty, dressed in a bright blue frock coat, nankeen trousers, and a white waistcoat, having the appearance and accent of an Englishman, presented himself before the mayor of Marseilles.
column3: The day after that in which the scene we have just described had taken place on the road between Bellegarde and Beaucaire, a man of about thirty or two and thirty, dressed in a bright blue frock coat, nankeen trousers, and a white waistcoat, having the appearance and accent of an Englishman, presented himself before the mayor of Marseilles.

column2: Sir, said he, "I am chief clerk of the house of Thomson & French, of Rome.
column3: Sir, said he, "I am chief clerk of the house of Thomson and French, of Rome.

column2: We are, and have been these ten years, connected with the house of Morrel & Son, of Marseilles.
column3: We are, and have been these ten years, connected with the house of Morrel and Son, of Marseilles.

column2: We have a hundred thousand francs or thereabouts loaned on their securities, and we are a little uneasy at reports that have reached us that the firm is on the brink of ruin.
column3: We have a hundred thousand francs or thereabouts loaned on their securities, and we are a little uneasy at reports that have reached us that the firm is on the brink of ruin.

column2: I have come, therefore, express from Rome, to ask you for information."
column3: I have come, therefore, express from Rome, to ask you for information."

column2: Sir, replied the mayor.
column3: Sir, replied the mayor.

column2: I know very well that during the last four or five years misfortune has seemed to pursue M. Morrel.	I know very well that during the last four or five years misfortune has seemed to pursue m Morrel.
column3: false

column2: He has lost four or five vessels, and suffered by three or four bankruptcies; but it is not for me, although I am a creditor myself to the amount of ten thousand francs, to give any information as to the state of his finances.
column3: He has lost four or five vessels, and suffered by three or four bankruptcies; but it is not for me, although I am a creditor myself to the amount of ten thousand francs, to give any information as to the state of his finances.

column2: Ask of me, as mayor, what is my opinion of M. Morrel, and I shall say that he is a man honorable to the last degree, and who has up to this time fulfilled every engagement with scrupulous punctuality. This is all I can say, sir; if you wish to learn more, address yourself to M. de Boville, the inspector of prisons, No. 15, Rue de Nouailles; he has, I believe, two hundred thousand francs in Morrel's hands, and if there be any grounds for apprehension, as this is a greater amount than mine, you will most probably find him better informed than myself."
column3: Ask of me, as mayor, what is my opinion of m Morrel, and I shall say that he is a man honorable to the last degree, and who has up to this time fulfilled every engagement with scrupulous punctuality. This is all I can say, sir; if you wish to learn more, address yourself to m de Boville, the inspector of prisons, no fifteen, Rue de Nouailles; he has, I believe, two hundred thousand francs in Morrel's hands, and if there be any grounds for apprehension, as this is a greater amount than mine, you will most probably find him better informed than myself."

column2: The Englishman seemed to appreciate this extreme delicacy, made his bow and went away, proceeding with a characteristic British stride towards the street mentioned.
column3: The Englishman seemed to appreciate this extreme delicacy, made his bow and went away, proceeding with a characteristic British stride towards the street mentioned.

column2: M. de Boville was in his private room, and the Englishman, on perceiving him, made a gesture of surprise, which seemed to indicate that it was not the first time he had been in his presence. As to M. de Boville, he was in such a state of despair, that it was evident all the faculties of his mind, absorbed in the thought which occupied him at the moment, did not allow either his memory or his imagination to stray to the past.
column3: M. de Boville was in his private room, and the Englishman, on perceiving him, made a gesture of surprise, which seemed to indicate that it was not the first time he had been in his presence. As to m de Boville, he was in such a state of despair, that it was evident all the faculties of his mind, absorbed in the thought which occupied him at the moment, did not allow either his memory or his imagination to stray to the past.

column2: The Englishman, with the coolness of his nation, addressed him in terms nearly similar to those with which he had accosted the mayor of Marseilles.
column3: The Englishman, with the coolness of his nation, addressed him in terms nearly similar to those with which he had accosted the mayor of Marseilles.

column2: Oh, sir, exclaimed M. de Boville, "your fears are unfortunately but too well founded, and you see before you a man in despair.
column3: Oh, sir, exclaimed m de Boville, "your fears are unfortunately but too well founded, and you see before you a man in despair.

column2: I had two hundred thousand francs placed in the hands of Morrel & Son; these two hundred thousand francs were the dowry of my daughter, who was to be married in a fortnight, and these two hundred thousand francs were payable, half on the 15th of this month, and the other half on the 15th of next month.
column3: I had two hundred thousand francs placed in the hands of Morrel and Son; these two hundred thousand francs were the dowry of my daughter, who was to be married in a fortnight, and these two hundred thousand francs were payable, half on the fifteenth of this month, and the other half on the fifteenth of next month.

column2: I had informed M. Morrel of my desire to have these payments punctually, and he has been here within the last half-hour to tell me that if his ship, the Pharaon, did not come into port on the 15th, he would be wholly unable to make this payment."
column3: I had informed m Morrel of my desire to have these payments punctually, and he has been here within the last half hour to tell me that if his ship, the Pharaon, did not come into port on the fifteenth, he would be wholly unable to make this payment."

column2: But, said the Englishman, "this looks very much like a suspension of payment."
column3: But, said the Englishman, "this looks very much like a suspension of payment."

column2: It looks more like bankruptcy! exclaimed M. de Boville despairingly.
column3: It looks more like bankruptcy! exclaimed m de Boville despairingly.

column2: The Englishman appeared to reflect a moment, and then said,--"From which it would appear, sir, that this credit inspires you with considerable apprehension?"
column3: The Englishman appeared to reflect a moment, and then said,--"From which it would appear, sir, that this credit inspires you with considerable apprehension?"

column2: To tell you the truth, I consider it lost.
column3: To tell you the truth, I consider it lost.

column2: Well, then, I will buy it of you!
column3: Well, then, I will buy it of you!

column2: You?
column3: You?

column2: Yes, I!
column3: Yes, I!

column2: But at a tremendous discount, of course?
column3: But at a tremendous discount, of course?

column2: No, for two hundred thousand francs.	No, for two hundred thousand francs.
column3: true

column2: Our house," added the Englishman with a laugh, "does not do things in that way."
column3: Our house," added the Englishman with a laugh, "does not do things in that way."

column2: And you will pay--
column3: And you will pay--

column2: Ready money. And the Englishman drew from his pocket a bundle of bank-notes, which might have been twice the sum M. de Boville feared to lose.
column3: Ready money. And the Englishman drew from his pocket a bundle of bank notes, which might have been twice the sum m de Boville feared to lose.

column2: A ray of joy passed across M. de Boville's countenance, yet he made an effort at self-control, and said,--"Sir, I ought to tell you that, in all probability, you will not realize six per cent of this sum."
column3: A ray of joy passed across m de Boville's countenance, yet he made an effort at self control, and said,--"Sir, I ought to tell you that, in all probability, you will not realize six per cent of this sum."

column2: That's no affair of mine, replied the Englishman, "that is the affair of the house of Thomson & French, in whose name I act.
column3: That's no affair of mine, replied the Englishman, "that is the affair of the house of Thomson and French, in whose name I act.

column2: They have, perhaps, some motive to serve in hastening the ruin of a rival firm. But all I know, sir, is, that I am ready to hand you over this sum in exchange for your assignment of the debt.
column3: They have, perhaps, some motive to serve in hastening the ruin of a rival firm. But all I know, sir, is, that I am ready to hand you over this sum in exchange for your assignment of the debt.

column2: I only ask a brokerage."
column3: I only ask a brokerage."

column2: Of course, that is perfectly just, cried M. de Boville.
column3: Of course, that is perfectly just, cried m de Boville.

column2: The commission is usually one and a half; will you have two--three--five per cent, or even more?	The commission is usually one and a half; will you have two-three-five per cent, or even more?

column2: Whatever you say."
column3: Whatever you say."

column2: Sir, replied the Englishman, laughing, "I am like my house, and do not do such things--no, the commission I ask is quite different."
column3: Sir, replied the Englishman, laughing, "I am like my house, and do not do such things-no, the commission I ask is quite different."

column2: Name it, sir, I beg.
column3: Name it, sir, I beg.

column2: You are the inspector of prisons?
column3: You are the inspector of prisons?

column2: I have been so these fourteen years.
column3: I have been so these fourteen years.

column2: You keep the registers of entries and departures?
column3: You keep the registers of entries and departures?

column2: I do.
column3: I do.

column2: To these registers there are added notes relative to the prisoners?
column3: To these registers there are added notes relative to the prisoners?

column2: There are special reports on every prisoner.
column3: There are special reports on every prisoner.

column2: Well, sir, I was educated at home by a poor devil of an abbe, who disappeared suddenly.	Well, sir, I was educated at home by a poor devil of an abbe, who disappeared suddenly.
column3: true

column2: I have since learned that he was confined in the Chateau d'If, and I should like to learn some particulars of his death."
column3: I have since learned that he was confined in the Chateau d'If, and I should like to learn some particulars of his death."

column2: What was his name?
column3: What was his name?

column2: The Abbe Faria.
column3: The Abbe Faria.

column2: Oh, I recollect him perfectly, cried M. de Boville; "he was crazy."
column3: Oh, I recollect him perfectly, cried m de Boville; "he was crazy."

column2: So they said.
column3: So they said.

column2: Oh, he was, decidedly.
column3: Oh, he was, decidedly.

column2: Very possibly; but what sort of madness was it?
column3: Very possibly; but what sort of madness was it?

column2: He pretended to know of an immense treasure, and offered vast sums to the government if they would liberate him.
column3: He pretended to know of an immense treasure, and offered vast sums to the government if they would liberate him.

column2: Poor devil!--and he is dead?
column3: Poor devil!--and he is dead?

column2: Yes, sir, five or six months ago--last February.
column3: Yes, sir, five or six months ago-last February.

column2: You have a good memory, sir, to recollect dates so well.
column3: You have a good memory, sir, to recollect dates so well.

column2: I recollect this, because the poor devil's death was accompanied by a singular incident.
column3: I recollect this, because the poor devil's death was accompanied by a singular incident.

column2: May I ask what that was? said the Englishman with an expression of curiosity, which a close observer would have been astonished at discovering in his phlegmatic countenance.
column3: May I ask what that was? said the Englishman with an expression of curiosity, which a close observer would have been astonished at discovering in his phlegmatic countenance.

column2: Oh dear, yes, sir; the abbe's dungeon was forty or fifty feet distant from that of one of Bonaparte's emissaries,--one of those who had contributed the most to the return of the usurper in 1815,--a very resolute and very dangerous man.
column3: Oh dear, yes, sir; the abbe's dungeon was forty or fifty feet distant from that of one of Bonaparte's emissaries,--one of those who had contributed the most to the return of the usurper in eighteen fifteen,--a very resolute and very dangerous man.

column2: Indeed! said the Englishman.
column3: Indeed! said the Englishman.

column2: Yes, replied M. de Boville; "I myself had occasion to see this man in 1816 or 1817, and we could only go into his dungeon with a file of soldiers.
column3: Yes, replied m de Boville; "I myself had occasion to see this man in eighteen sixteen or eighteen seventeen, and we could only go into his dungeon with a file of soldiers.

column2: That man made a deep impression on me; I shall never forget his countenance!"
column3: That man made a deep impression on me; I shall never forget his countenance!"

column2: The Englishman smiled imperceptibly.
column3: The Englishman smiled imperceptibly.

column2: And you say, sir, he interposed, "that the two dungeons"--
column3: And you say, sir, he interposed, "that the two dungeons"--

column2: Were separated by a distance of fifty feet; but it appears that this Edmond Dantes--
column3: Were separated by a distance of fifty feet; but it appears that this Edmond Dantes--

column2: This dangerous man's name was--
column3: This dangerous man's name was--

column2: Edmond Dantes.	Edmond Dantes.
column3: true

column2: It appears, sir, that this Edmond Dantes had procured tools, or made them, for they found a tunnel through which the prisoners held communication with one another."
column3: It appears, sir, that this Edmond Dantes had procured tools, or made them, for they found a tunnel through which the prisoners held communication with one another."

column2: This tunnel was dug, no doubt, with an intention of escape?
column3: This tunnel was dug, no doubt, with an intention of escape?

column2: No doubt; but unfortunately for the prisoners, the Abbe Faria had an attack of catalepsy, and died.
column3: No doubt; but unfortunately for the prisoners, the Abbe Faria had an attack of catalepsy, and died.

column2: That must have cut short the projects of escape.
column3: That must have cut short the projects of escape.

column2: For the dead man, yes, replied M. de Boville, "but not for the survivor; on the contrary, this Dantes saw a means of accelerating his escape.
column3: For the dead man, yes, replied m de Boville, "but not for the survivor; on the contrary, this Dantes saw a means of accelerating his escape.

column2: He, no doubt, thought that prisoners who died in the Chateau d'If were interred in an ordinary burial-ground, and he conveyed the dead man into his own cell, took his place in the sack in which they had sewed up the corpse, and awaited the moment of interment."
column3: He, no doubt, thought that prisoners who died in the Chateau d'If were interred in an ordinary burial ground, and he conveyed the dead man into his own cell, took his place in the sack in which they had sewed up the corpse, and awaited the moment of interment."

column2: It was a bold step, and one that showed some courage, remarked the Englishman.
column3: It was a bold step, and one that showed some courage, remarked the Englishman.

column2: As I have already told you, sir, he was a very dangerous man; and, fortunately, by his own act disembarrassed the government of the fears it had on his account.
column3: As I have already told you, sir, he was a very dangerous man; and, fortunately, by his own act disembarrassed the government of the fears it had on his account.

column2: How was that?
column3: How was that?

column2: How?	How?
column3: true

column2: Do you not comprehend?"
column3: Do you not comprehend?"

column2: No.
column3: no

column2: The Chateau d'If has no cemetery, and they simply throw the dead into the sea, after fastening a thirty-six pound cannon-ball to their feet.
column3: The Chateau d'If has no cemetery, and they simply throw the dead into the sea, after fastening a thirty six pound cannon ball to their feet.

column2: Well, observed the Englishman as if he were slow of comprehension.
column3: Well, observed the Englishman as if he were slow of comprehension.

column2: Well, they fastened a thirty-six pound ball to his feet, and threw him into the sea.
column3: Well, they fastened a thirty six pound ball to his feet, and threw him into the sea.

column2: Really! exclaimed the Englishman.
column3: Really! exclaimed the Englishman.

column2: Yes, sir, continued the inspector of prisons.
column3: Yes, sir, continued the inspector of prisons.

column2: You may imagine the amazement of the fugitive when he found himself flung headlong over the rocks!	You may imagine the amazement of the fugitive when he found himself flung headlong over the rocks!
column3: true

column2: I should like to have seen his face at that moment."
column3: I should like to have seen his face at that moment."

column2: That would have been difficult.
column3: That would have been difficult.

column2: No matter, replied De Boville, in supreme good-humor at the certainty of recovering his two hundred thousand francs,--"no matter, I can fancy it." And he shouted with laughter.
column3: No matter, replied De Boville, in supreme good humor at the certainty of recovering his two hundred thousand francs,--"no matter, I can fancy it." And he shouted with laughter.

column2: So can I, said the Englishman, and he laughed too; but he laughed as the English do, "at the end of his teeth."
column3: So can I, said the Englishman, and he laughed too; but he laughed as the English do, "at the end of his teeth."

column2: And so, continued the Englishman who first gained his composure, "he was drowned?"
column3: And so, continued the Englishman who first gained his composure, "he was drowned?"

column2: Unquestionably.
column3: Unquestionably.

column2: So that the governor got rid of the dangerous and the crazy prisoner at the same time?
column3: So that the governor got rid of the dangerous and the crazy prisoner at the same time?

column2: Precisely.
column3: Precisely.

column2: But some official document was drawn up as to this affair, I suppose? inquired the Englishman.
column3: But some official document was drawn up as to this affair, I suppose? inquired the Englishman.

column2: Yes, yes, the mortuary deposition.	Yes, yes, the mortuary deposition.
column3: true

column2: You understand, Dantes' relations, if he had any, might have some interest in knowing if he were dead or alive."
column3: You understand, Dantes' relations, if he had any, might have some interest in knowing if he were dead or alive."

column2: So that now, if there were anything to inherit from him, they may do so with easy conscience.	So that now, if there were anything to inherit from him, they may do so with easy conscience.
column3: true

column2: He is dead, and no mistake about it."
column3: He is dead, and no mistake about it."

column2: Oh, yes; and they may have the fact attested whenever they please.
column3: Oh, yes; and they may have the fact attested whenever they please.

column2: So be it, said the Englishman.
column3: So be it, said the Englishman.

column2: But to return to these registers.
column3: But to return to these registers.

column2: True, this story has diverted our attention from them.	True, this story has diverted our attention from them.
column3: true

column2: Excuse me."
column3: Excuse me."

column2: Excuse you for what?	Excuse you for what?
column3: true

column2: For the story?
column3: For the story?

column2: By no means; it really seems to me very curious."
column3: By no means; it really seems to me very curious."

column2: Yes, indeed.	Yes, indeed.
column3: true

column2: So, sir, you wish to see all relating to the poor abbe, who really was gentleness itself."
column3: So, sir, you wish to see all relating to the poor abbe, who really was gentleness itself."

column2: Yes, you will much oblige me.
column3: Yes, you will much oblige me.

column2: Go into my study here, and I will show it to you. And they both entered M. de Boville's study.
column3: Go into my study here, and I will show it to you. And they both entered m de Boville's study.

column2: Everything was here arranged in perfect order; each register had its number, each file of papers its place.
column3: Everything was here arranged in perfect order; each register had its number, each file of papers its place.

column2: The inspector begged the Englishman to seat himself in an arm-chair, and placed before him the register and documents relative to the Chateau d'If, giving him all the time he desired for the examination, while De Boville seated himself in a corner, and began to read his newspaper.
column3: The inspector begged the Englishman to seat himself in an arm chair, and placed before him the register and documents relative to the Chateau d'If, giving him all the time he desired for the examination, while De Boville seated himself in a corner, and began to read his newspaper.

column2: The Englishman easily found the entries relative to the Abbe Faria; but it seemed that the history which the inspector had related interested him greatly, for after having perused the first documents he turned over the leaves until he reached the deposition respecting Edmond Dantes.
column3: The Englishman easily found the entries relative to the Abbe Faria; but it seemed that the history which the inspector had related interested him greatly, for after having perused the first documents he turned over the leaves until he reached the deposition respecting Edmond Dantes.

column2: There he found everything arranged in due order,--the accusation, examination, Morrel's petition, M. de Villefort's marginal notes.
column3: There he found everything arranged in due order,--the accusation, examination, Morrel's petition, m de Villefort's marginal notes.

column2: He folded up the accusation quietly, and put it as quietly in his pocket; read the examination, and saw that the name of Noirtier was not mentioned in it; perused, too, the application dated 10th April, 1815, in which Morrel, by the deputy procureur's advice, exaggerated with the best intentions (for Napoleon was then on the throne) the services Dantes had rendered to the imperial cause--services which Villefort's certificates rendered indispensable.
column3: He folded up the accusation quietly, and put it as quietly in his pocket; read the examination, and saw that the name of Noirtier was not mentioned in it; perused, too, the application dated the tenth of april eighteen fifteen, in which Morrel, by the deputy procureur's advice, exaggerated with the best intentions (for Napoleon was then on the throne) the services Dantes had rendered to the imperial cause-services which Villefort's certificates rendered indispensable.

column2: Then he saw through the whole thing.
column3: Then he saw through the whole thing.

column2: This petition to Napoleon, kept back by Villefort, had become, under the second restoration, a terrible weapon against him in the hands of the king's attorney.
column3: This petition to Napoleon, kept back by Villefort, had become, under the second restoration, a terrible weapon against him in the hands of the king's attorney.

column2: He was no longer astonished when he searched on to find in the register this note, placed in a bracket against his name:--
column3: He was no longer astonished when he searched on to find in the register this note, placed in a bracket against his name:--

column2: Edmond Dantes.
column3: Edmond Dantes.

column2: An inveterate Bonapartist; took an active part in the return from the Island of Elba.
column3: An inveterate Bonapartist; took an active part in the return from the Island of Elba.

column2: To be kept in strict solitary confinement, and to be closely watched and guarded.
column3: To be kept in strict solitary confinement, and to be closely watched and guarded.

column2: Beneath these lines was written in another hand: "See note above--nothing can be done." He compared the writing in the bracket with the writing of the certificate placed beneath Morrel's petition, and discovered that the note in the bracket was the same writing as the certificate--that is to say, was in Villefort's handwriting.
column3: Beneath these lines was written in another hand: "See note above-nothing can be done." column2: As to the note which accompanied this, the Englishman understood that it might have been added by some inspector who had taken a momentary interest in Dantes' situation, but who had, from the remarks we have quoted, found it impossible to give any effect to the interest he had felt.
column3: As to the note which accompanied this, the Englishman understood that it might have been added by some inspector who had taken a momentary interest in Dantes' situation, but who had, from the remarks we have quoted, found it impossible to give any effect to the interest he had felt.

column2: As we have said, the inspector, from discretion, and that he might not disturb the Abbe Faria's pupil in his researches, had seated himself in a corner, and was reading Le Drapeau Blanc.
column3: As we have said, the inspector, from discretion, and that he might not disturb the Abbe Faria's pupil in his researches, had seated himself in a corner, and was reading Le Drapeau Blanc.

column2: He did not see the Englishman fold up and place in his pocket the accusation written by Danglars under the arbor of La Reserve, and which had the postmark, "Marseilles, 27th Feb., delivery 6 o'clock, P.M." But it must be said that if he had seen it, he attached so little importance to this scrap of paper, and so much importance to his two hundred thousand francs, that he would not have opposed whatever the Englishman might do, however irregular it might be.
column3: He did not see the Englishman fold up and place in his pocket the accusation written by Danglars under the arbor of La Reserve, and which had the postmark, "Marseilles, the twenty seventh of february, delivery six o'clock, p m" But it must be said that if he had seen it, he attached so little importance to this scrap of paper, and so much importance to his two hundred thousand francs, that he would not have opposed whatever the Englishman might do, however irregular it might be.

column2: Thanks, said the latter, closing the register with a slam, "I have all I want; now it is for me to perform my promise.
column3: Thanks, said the latter, closing the register with a slam, "I have all I want; now it is for me to perform my promise.

column2: Give me a simple assignment of your debt; acknowledge therein the receipt of the cash, and I will hand you over the money." He rose, gave his seat to M. de Boville, who took it without ceremony, and quickly drew up the required assignment, while the Englishman counted out the bank-notes on the other side of the desk.
column3: Give me a simple assignment of your debt; acknowledge therein the receipt of the cash, and I will hand you over the money."
